title: The 3 A's of awesome - Neil Pasricha

multiple-choice.question: What was the speaker's motivation for starting the "1000 Awesome Things" blog?

options.label: A
options.text: To share his life story with the world.

options.label: B
options.text: To focus on the positive aspects of life during a difficult time.

options.label: C
options.text: To showcase his writing skills and gain popularity.

options.label: D
options.text: To make money through advertising and sponsorships.

multiple-choice.question: What are the "Three A's of Awesome" according to the speaker?
What does the speaker mean by "attitude" in the context of the "Three A's of Awesome"?

options.label: A
options.text: Having a positive outlook on life and choosing to move forward despite challenges.

options.label: B
options.text: Being stubborn and refusing to change one's perspective.

options.label: C
options.text: Having a negative attitude towards life and expecting the worst.

options.label: D
options.text: Being neutral and not taking a stance on anything.

multiple-choice.question: How does the speaker describe the importance of "awareness" in the context of the "Three A's of Awesome"?

options.label: A
options.text: Being aware of one's surroundings and appreciating the small wonders in life.

options.label: B
options.text: Being aware of one's own strengths and weaknesses.

options.label: C
options.text: Being aware of the opinions of others and trying to please them.

options.label: D
options.text: Being aware of the latest trends and technologies.

multiple-choice.question: What does the speaker mean by "authenticity" in the context of the "Three A's of Awesome"?

options.label: A
options.text: Being true to oneself and not trying to pretend to be someone else.

options.label: B
options.text: Trying to fit in with others and being like everyone else.

options.label: C
options.text: Being fake and pretending to be someone else.

options.label: D
options.text: Being neutral and not taking a stance on anything.

multiple-choice.question: What is the story of Rosie Greer, and how does it relate to the concept of "authenticity"?

options.label: A
options.text: Rosie Greer was a football player who loved needlepoint and was unapologetic about his hobby.

options.label: B
options.text: Rosie Greer was a football player who hated needlepoint and thought it was silly.

options.label: C
options.text: Rosie Greer was a needlepoint enthusiast who loved football and tried to combine the two.

options.label: D
options.text: Rosie Greer was a football player who had no interest in needlepoint.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's message about the importance of living in the present moment?

options.label: A
options.text: We should focus on the past and learn from our mistakes.

options.label: B
options.text: We should focus on the future and plan for what's to come.

options.label: C
options.text: We should live in the present moment and appreciate the small joys in life.

options.label: D
options.text: We should ignore the present moment and focus on our goals.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's perspective on the fleeting nature of life?

options.label: A
options.text: Life is long and we have plenty of time to experience everything.

options.label: B
options.text: Life is short and we should make the most of the time we have.

options.label: C
options.text: Life is unpredictable and we should be prepared for anything.

options.label: D
options.text: Life is boring and we should try to make it more exciting.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's message about the importance of appreciating the small things in life?

options.label: A
options.text: We should focus on the big things in life and ignore the small things.

options.label: B
options.text: We should appreciate the small things in life because they make life worth living.

options.label: C
options.text: We should take the small things in life for granted and focus on our goals.

options.label: D
options.text: We should ignore the small things in life and focus on our problems.

multiple-choice.question: What is the overall message of the speaker's talk?

options.label: A
options.text: Life is difficult and we should be prepared for challenges.

options.label: B
options.text: Life is short and we should make the most of the time we have.

options.label: C
options.text: Life is boring and we should try to make it more exciting.

options.label: D
options.text: Life is awesome and we should appreciate the small joys that make it worth living.

title: On reading the Koran - Lesley Hazleton

multiple-choice.question: What is the Quranic idea of paradise often misunderstood as?

options.label: A
options.text: A beautiful garden with plenty of fruits and flowers.

options.label: D
options.text: A location with plenty of wealth and riches.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, why do people often give up reading the Quran?

options.label: C
options.text: Because of its "otherness" and being a "wearysome confused jumble".

multiple-choice.question: How did the speaker approach reading the Quran?

options.label: A
options.text: By reading it quickly and taking notes.

options.label: B
options.text: By reading four translations side by side, along with a transliteration and the original Arabic.

options.label: C
options.text: By listening to an audio version.

options.label: D
options.text: By reading a summary of the book.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the Arabic language in understanding the Quran?

options.label: A
options.text: It is the language of the prophet Muhammad.

options.label: B
options.text: It is the language in which the Quran was originally written.

options.label: C
options.text: The Quran's meaning and rhythm are lost in translation, and it is best understood in Arabic.

options.label: D
options.text: Arabic is a difficult language to learn.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's background in relation to reading the Quran?

options.label: A
options.text: The speaker is a Muslim scholar.

options.label: B
options.text: The speaker is an agnostic Jew who has written about Islamic history.

options.label: C
options.text: The speaker is a Quranic translator.

options.label: D
options.text: The speaker has no prior knowledge of the Quran.

multiple-choice.question: What does the Quran say about the environment and humans' role in it?

options.label: A
options.text: Humans are the owners of the earth and can do as they please.

options.label: B
options.text: Humans are mere stewards of God's creation and should take care of the environment.

options.label: C
options.text: The Quran does not mention the environment.

options.label: D
options.text: The Quran says that humans should exploit the earth's resources.

multiple-choice.question: How does the Quran address women?

options.label: A
options.text: The Quran only addresses men and ignores women.

options.label: B
options.text: The Quran includes women and talks about "believing men and believing women".

options.label: C
options.text: The Quran says that women are inferior to men.

options.label: D
options.text: The Quran does not mention women at all.

multiple-choice.question: What is the context of the infamous verse about killing unbelievers?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a general command to kill all non-Muslims.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a specific permission to fight in the context of the conquest of Mecca.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a verse that has been misinterpreted and does not actually say that.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a verse that only applies to certain groups of people.

multiple-choice.question: What does the Quran say about the meaning of its verses?

options.label: A
options.text: All verses have a clear and definite meaning.

options.label: B
options.text: Some verses are definite in meaning, while others are ambiguous.

options.label: C
options.text: The Quran does not comment on the meaning of its verses.

options.label: D
options.text: The meaning of the verses is only known to the prophet Muhammad.

multiple-choice.question: What is the actual meaning of the word "hurris" in the Quran?

options.label: C
options.text: A type of fruit or flower.

options.label: D
options.text: The Quran does not explain the meaning of this word.

title: The Eisenhower matrix: understanding task management

multiple-choice.question: What is the main benefit of using a good time management strategy?

options.label: B
options.text: Increasing the number of tasks to complete

multiple-choice.question: What is the Eisenhower Matrix used for?

options.label: C
options.text: Prioritizing tasks by both urgency and importance

multiple-choice.question: What type of tasks should be done first according to the Eisenhower Matrix?

options.label: A
options.text: Less important and less urgent tasks

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the "Schedule Sector" in the Eisenhower Matrix?

options.label: A
options.text: To list tasks that need to be done today

options.label: B
options.text: To list tasks that are important but less urgent

options.label: C
options.text: To list tasks that can be delegated

options.label: D
options.text: To list tasks that should be eliminated

multiple-choice.question: What type of tasks should be delegated according to the Eisenhower Matrix?
How should you keep track of delegated tasks?

options.label: B
options.text: By checking back on their progress via email, telephone, or meeting

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the fourth quadrant in the Eisenhower Matrix?

options.label: A
options.text: To list tasks that need to be done first

options.label: B
options.text: To list tasks that are important but less urgent

options.label: C
options.text: To list tasks that can be delegated

options.label: D
options.text: To sort out and eliminate tasks that should not be done

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a bad habit that should be stopped according to the Eisenhower Matrix?

options.label: B
options.text: Surfing the internet without a reason

multiple-choice.question: What did Dwight Eisenhower say about importance and urgency?

options.label: A
options.text: What's important is always urgent and what's urgent is always important

options.label: B
options.text: What's important is seldom urgent and what's urgent is seldom important

options.label: C
options.text: What's important is never urgent and what's urgent is never important

options.label: D
options.text: What's important is always important and what's urgent is always urgent

multiple-choice.question: Where can you find more information about the Eisenhower Matrix?

title: Mysteries of vernacular: Bewilder - Jessica Oreck and Rachael Teel

multiple-choice.question: What is the root of the word "bewilder"?
What was the initial meaning of the Old English word "deor"?

options.label: D
options.text: A ruminant of the family Cervidae

multiple-choice.question: What is the meaning of the word "wilderness"?

options.label: C
options.text: A tract of uncultivated land, primarily inhabited by undomesticated beasts

options.label: D
options.text: A ruminant of the family Cervidae

multiple-choice.question: What was the original meaning of the word "wilder"?

options.label: A
options.text: To lead someone astray or lure them into the woods

multiple-choice.question: What is the function of the prefix "be" in the word "bewilder"?

options.label: A
options.text: To indicate a reversal of meaning

options.label: D
options.text: To indicate a change in tense

multiple-choice.question: What is the current definition of the word "bewilder"?

options.label: A
options.text: To lead someone astray or lure them into the woods

multiple-choice.question: How did the word "bewilder" evolve from its original meaning?

options.label: A
options.text: Through a process of linguistic simplification

options.label: B
options.text: Through a process of linguistic complication

options.label: C
options.text: Through a combination of Old English words and prefixes

options.label: D
options.text: Through a change in cultural context

options.label: A
options.text: They are unrelated words with different etymologies

options.label: B
options.text: They are cognates with similar meanings

options.label: C
options.text: They are variants of the same word with different prefixes

options.label: D
options.text: They are words that have evolved from a common root

options.label: A
options.text: It is the direct source of the word "bewilder"

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: It is a cognate of the word "bewilder"

multiple-choice.question: How has the meaning of the word "bewilder" changed over time?

options.label: A
options.text: It has remained constant and unchanged

options.label: B
options.text: It has evolved from a literal to a figurative meaning

options.label: C
options.text: It has evolved from a figurative to a literal meaning

options.label: D
options.text: It has changed from a positive to a negative connotation

title: The walk from "no" to "yes" - William Ury

multiple-choice.question: What is the story about the 17 camels and the three sons trying to convey?

options.label: A
options.text: The importance of effective communication in negotiations.

options.label: B
options.text: The difficulty of dividing assets equally among parties.

options.label: C
options.text: The need to think creatively and find a new perspective in difficult negotiations.

options.label: D
options.text: The role of a third party in resolving disputes.

multiple-choice.question: What is the "third side" in a conflict, according to the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: A neutral third party that mediates between two opposing sides.

options.label: B
options.text: The surrounding community that can play a constructive role in resolving the conflict.

options.label: C
options.text: The opposing side in a conflict.

options.label: D
options.text: A group of experts who provide advice on conflict resolution.

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of the third side in a conflict, according to the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: To take sides and support one party over the other.

options.label: B
options.text: To provide financial support to one or both parties.

options.label: C
options.text: To remind the parties of what's really at stake and help them find a resolution.

options.label: D
options.text: To impose a solution on the parties.

multiple-choice.question: What is the story of Abraham, and how is it relevant to the Middle East conflict?

options.label: A
options.text: Abraham was a great warrior who conquered the Middle East, and his legacy is still celebrated today.

options.label: B
options.text: Abraham was a prophet who preached unity and hospitality, and his message is still relevant today.

options.label: C
options.text: Abraham was a king who ruled over the Middle East, and his descendants are still fighting over his legacy.

options.label: D
options.text: Abraham was a mythological figure who has no relevance to the Middle East conflict.

multiple-choice.question: What is the Abraham Path, and what is its purpose?

options.label: A
options.text: A physical path that follows the footsteps of Abraham, aimed at promoting tourism in the Middle East.

options.label: B
options.text: A metaphorical path that represents the journey towards peace and reconciliation in the Middle East.

options.label: C
options.text: A historical path that retraces the steps of Abraham, aimed at educating people about his life and legacy.

options.label: D
options.text: A virtual path that connects people from different cultures and backgrounds, aimed at promoting understanding and empathy.

multiple-choice.question: How does the speaker suggest that the Abraham Path can help to resolve the Middle East conflict?

options.label: A
options.text: By providing a platform for people to express their grievances and demands.

options.label: B
options.text: By promoting economic development and cooperation among different communities.

options.label: C
options.text: By creating a sense of shared identity and common purpose among people from different backgrounds.

options.label: D
options.text: By imposing a solution on the parties involved.

multiple-choice.question: What is the concept of "going to the balcony" in conflict resolution, according to the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: Taking a break from negotiations to reflect on one's position and goals.

options.label: B
options.text: Seeking the advice of a neutral third party.

options.label: C
options.text: Trying to see things from the other side's perspective.

options.label: D
options.text: Imposing one's own solution on the other party.

multiple-choice.question: How does the speaker suggest that individuals can make a difference in conflict resolution?

options.label: A
options.text: By taking a strong stance and advocating for one side or the other.

options.label: B
options.text: By providing financial support to one or both parties.

options.label: C
options.text: By engaging in small acts of kindness and empathy, such as listening to someone from a different culture.

options.label: D
options.text: By imposing a solution on the parties involved.

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential impact of the Abraham Path on local communities, according to the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: It could lead to increased conflict and tension among different communities.

options.label: B
options.text: It could provide economic benefits and promote cultural exchange among different communities.

options.label: C
options.text: It could have no impact on local communities.

options.label: D
options.text: It could lead to the displacement of local communities.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's overall message about conflict resolution?

options.label: A
options.text: That it is impossible to resolve conflicts peacefully.

options.label: B
options.text: That conflicts can only be resolved through the use of force.

options.label: C
options.text: That conflicts can be transformed and resolved through creative and peaceful means.

options.label: D
options.text: That conflicts are inevitable and will always be a part of human society.

title: Labor Day: Is it really a necessary holiday?

multiple-choice.question: What significant event occurred in Canada in 1872 that changed the labor landscape?

options.label: A
options.text: Thousands of Ottawa laborers went on strike to protest wage cuts.

options.label: B
options.text: Canada wiped the anti-union law from its books, making unions legal.

options.label: C
options.text: The first Labor Day parade was held in Toronto.

options.label: D
options.text: The Canadian government imposed longer work hours and pay cuts.

multiple-choice.question: Who is credited with suggesting a workers' parade to New York City's Central Labor Union in 1882?
What was the original date chosen for the Labor Day parade in New York City in 1882?
What was the main demand of the laborers during the 1882 Labor Day parade in New York City?
Which state was the first to legalize the Labor Day holiday in 1887?
What event in 1894 led to Labor Day becoming a federal holiday?

options.label: B
options.text: The New York City Labor Day parade

multiple-choice.question: Who signed the bill making Labor Day a federal holiday in 1894?
What was the main reason for the decline of the US labor force in the second half of the 20th century?

options.label: A
options.text: Many factories closed, and jobs were outsourced to other countries.

options.label: B
options.text: Workers became less interested in unionizing.

options.label: D
options.text: The economy experienced a significant downturn.

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: By leisurely enjoying the holiday as summer's last day off

options.label: D
options.text: By going on strike to protest wage cuts

multiple-choice.question: What is the current state of the labor force in the United States?

options.label: B
options.text: The labor force is growing, with more workers unionizing.

options.label: C
options.text: The labor force is dwindling, with fewer workers unionizing.

options.label: D
options.text: The labor force is stagnant, with no significant changes.

title: Who won the space race? - Jeff Steers

multiple-choice.question: What event marked the beginning of the space race between the U.S. and U.S.S.R.?

options.label: A
options.text: The launch of the V-2 rocket by Germany in World War II.

options.label: B
options.text: The successful testing of the R-7 intercontinental ballistic missile by the Soviet Union.

options.label: C
options.text: The launch of Sputnik, the world's first man-made satellite, by the Soviet Union on October 4, 1957.

options.label: D
options.text: The launch of the Explorer satellite by the U.S. Army in January 1958.

multiple-choice.question: What was the significance of the V-2 rocket in the history of space exploration?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: It was the first intercontinental ballistic missile.

options.label: C
options.text: It was the first piece of human technology to enter space.

options.label: D
options.text: It was the first successful launch of a satellite by the United States.

Who was the first person to orbit the Earth?
What was the goal announced by President Kennedy in May 1961?

options.label: A
options.text: To put a man on the moon by the end of the 1960s.

options.label: B
options.text: To launch a satellite into orbit before the Soviet Union.

options.label: C
options.text: To develop a new intercontinental ballistic missile.

options.label: D
options.text: To establish a permanent space station in orbit.

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: The establishment of a permanent space station in orbit.

options.label: C
options.text: Advances in research and education, and the development of new technologies such as memory foam and LEDs.

options.label: D
options.text: The launch of a man to the moon before the Soviet Union.

multiple-choice.question: Who was the first American to orbit the Earth?
What was the name of the Soviet Premier who negotiated improving relations with U.S. President Nixon?
What was the significance of the Apollo program in the history of space exploration?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: It was the first manned mission to the moon.

options.label: C
options.text: It was the first joint mission between the U.S. and U.S.S.R.

options.label: D

title: RNAi: Slicing, dicing and serving your cells - Alex Dainis

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of RNA in a cell?

options.label: A
options.text: To act as a messenger between DNA and the ribosome

options.label: C
options.text: To direct amino acids to their targets

options.label: D
options.text: To take part in RNA interference (RNAi)

multiple-choice.question: What is RNA interference (RNAi)?

options.label: A
options.text: A process by which RNA creates DNA

options.label: B
options.text: A process by which RNA directs amino acids to their targets

options.label: C
options.text: A process by which RNA interferes with the expression of certain genes

options.label: D
options.text: A process by which RNA is destroyed by the cell

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of the protein dicer in RNAi?

options.label: B
options.text: To chop up long, double-stranded RNA molecules

options.label: D
options.text: To destroy RNA injected into the cell by an attacking virus

multiple-choice.question: What is the function of the RNA Silencing Complex (RISC)?

options.label: B
options.text: To chop up long, double-stranded RNA molecules

options.label: C
options.text: To target matching mRNA and slice it up

options.label: D
options.text: To destroy RNA injected into the cell by an attacking virus

multiple-choice.question: How was RNAi first discovered?

options.label: A
options.text: In petunias, when botanists trying to create deep purple blooms introduced a pigment-producing gene

options.label: B
options.text: In C. elegans, when scientists were studying the effects of RNA on gene expression

options.label: C
options.text: In humans, when researchers were studying the effects of RNA on cancer cells

options.label: D
options.text: In bacteria, when scientists were studying the effects of RNA on gene expression

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential therapeutic application of RNAi?

options.label: A
options.text: To manipulate what is happening within our own cells

options.label: B
options.text: To understand how things happen in our cells

options.label: D
options.text: To destroy RNA injected into the cell by an attacking virus

multiple-choice.question: How can RNAi be used to study gene function?

options.label: A
options.text: By introducing an RNAi construct for a specific gene and observing the effects

options.label: C
options.text: By chopping up long, double-stranded RNA molecules

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of the slicer protein in RISC?

options.label: B
options.text: To chop up long, double-stranded RNA molecules

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the mRNA that is targeted by RISC?

options.label: B
options.text: It is chopped up by dicer

options.label: C
options.text: It is sliced up by the slicer protein

options.label: D
options.text: It is destroyed by the cell

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential application of RNAi in medicine?

options.label: B
options.text: To understand how things happen in our cells

options.label: C
options.text: To manipulate what is happening within our own cells

options.label: D
options.text: To target RNA in tumor cells and turn off cancer-causing genes

options.label: A
